Running Debian GNU/Linux on OCTEON

1. Introduction

Debian is a very stable and well supported Linux distribution. From the Debian website (http://www.debian.org/) here is how they describe themselves:

    Debian is a free operating system (OS) for your computer. An operating
    system is the set of basic programs and utilities that make your computer
    run. Debian uses the Linux kernel (the core of an operating system), but
    most of the basic OS tools come from the GNU project; hence the name
    GNU/Linux.

    Debian GNU/Linux provides more than a pure OS: it comes with over 15490
    packages, precompiled software bundled up in a nice format for easy
    installation on your machine.

OCTEON runs the Debian GNU/Linux port for Mips processors Debian 8.0 distribution from Debian's website.

Quick links:

  • 1. Introduction
  • 2. Building the Kernel
  • 3. Setting up a Compact Flash
  • 4. Booting

  • 10. Compact Flash Layout
  • 11. OCTEON Customizations to Debian
  • 12. Sample Boot Log

2. Building the Kernel

A target has been added to the top level Linux makefile for building the kernel for Debian. The only difference from the standard Busybox based Linux is the absence of an initramfs filesystem. The commands below will build the Debian kernel.

    $ cd ${OCTEON_ROOT}/linux
    $ make -s kernel-deb # The target "debian" will also work
Note:
The Debian packages were built on a machine with 4KB pages. Although Debian will boot with other page sizes, some executables don't work properly. This will not affect binaries built with the Cavium toolchain, but O32 applications may have trouble. It is recommended you only run Debian with a 4KB page size.

3. Setting up a Compact Flash

Debian requires a more complicated compact flash layout than normal. Compact flash cards are normally formated with a single DOS FAT partition. For Debian, two partitions are need with two different filesystems (FAT and EXT3). The steps here will erase all data on the compact flash and reformat it for two partitions.

  • 1. Determine the device name for your compact flash reader/writer. When you plug the USB compact flash reader/writer into a USB port the Linux kernel will send information about it to the kernel log. After plugging in the reader/writer, use dmesg to view the log. Look for an entry similar to the one below near the end of the log. The device name is after the "Attached scsi removable disk". In this example, it is sda. 
            usb 1-2.4: new high speed USB device using address 22
        scsi17 : SCSI emulation for USB Mass Storage devices
          Vendor: ICSI      Model: IC1210        CF  Rev: 1.6F
          Type:   Direct-Access                      ANSI SCSI revision: 02
        Attached scsi removable disk sda at scsi17, channel 0, id 0, lun 0
        Attached scsi generic sg0 at scsi17, channel 0, id 0, lun 0,  type 0
        USB Mass Storage device found at 22
  • 2. Add the following lines to /etc/fstab. Replace "sda" with the device name determined from above. 
            /dev/sda1       /mnt/cf1        auto    noauto,noatime,user     0 0
        /dev/sda2       /mnt/cf2        ext3    noauto,noatime,user     0 0
  • 3. Create mount points for the compact flash. 
            $ mkdir -p /mnt/cf1
        $ mkdir -p /mnt/cf2
  • 4. Setup a 1GB (or larger) compact flash with the Debian filesystem and kernel. Make sure OCTEON_ROOT is set properly, then execute make from the linux/debian directory. All data on the flash will be erased. 
            $ make DISK=/dev/sda compact-flash
  • 5. At this point the Debian filesystem is ready. These steps normally only need to be performed once. In the future, the kernel may be upgraded without affecting the rest of the filesystem by using the flash target of the top level Linux makefile. 
            $ cd ${OCTEON_ROOT}/linux
        $ make -s kernel-deb flash

If you get an error message like the one below, be careful. This means the make script detect a disk device larger than 4GB. Compact flashes larger than 4GB are very rare. More than likely you mistakenly told the script to format your internal hard drive. If you really want to install on a device larger than 4GB, you must manually remove the check from the Makefile.

**************************************************
About to erase everything on /dev/sda.
Disk /dev/sda: 74.3 GB, 74355769344 bytes
You have 5 seconds to hit Control-C to stop this.
**************************************************
Refusing to destroy disk /dev/sda, larger than 4GB!

4. Booting

Once the compact flash is written, put it in the OCTEON board. The bootloader command to boot Debian is slightly different from the one used for the Busybox based filesystem. Debian requires the partition of the filesystem be passed to the kernel. The parameter root=/dev/sda2 tells the kernel to find the root filesystem on partition 2 of the compact flash. It is recommended that you add a bootloader alias cfroot. 

    Octeon ebt5800# setenv cfroot 'fatload ide 0 $(loadaddr) vmlinux.64;bootoctlinux $(loadaddr) coremask=ffff root=/dev/sda2'
    Octeon ebt5800# saveenv
    Octeon ebt5800# run cfroot
Note:
You can also add mem= to set the amount of memory (in megabytes) allocated to Linux. Setting it to 0 uses all available memory.

5. Networking

By default, the Debian system will attempt to configure eth0 (closest to the power switch) using DHCP. As part of the bootup messages it will display the address it receives from the DHCP server. Here is an example where OCTEON gets the IP address 192.168.16.166.

    Listening on LPF/eth0/00:0f:b7:10:01:7a
    Sending on   LPF/eth0/00:0f:b7:10:01:7a
    Sending on   Socket/fallback/fallback-net
    DHCPDISCOVER on eth0 to 255.255.255.255 port 67 interval 3
    DHCPOFFER from 192.168.16.10
    DHCPREQUEST on eth0 to 255.255.255.255 port 67
    DHCPACK from 192.168.16.10
    bound to 192.168.16.166 -- renewal in 43200 seconds.

OCTEON can be configure to use any of the available ethernet ports with either DHCP or a static IP address. The file /etc/network/interfaces controls how Debian configures the ports. For more information on this file, do a man interfaces.

6. Using SSH and SCP

The Debian system starts OpenSSH. It can be used to login and copy files to/from another unix machine. Note that the default OpenSSH configuration blocks access to accounts with empty passwords. This means that before you can use OpenSSH, you must set a password for the root account. Login using the serial port and issue passwd to set the root password. After this you can use ssh and scp to access OCTEON. 

    $ ssh root@<OCTEON ip address>
    $ scp file root@<OCTEON ip address>:

It is recommended that you use a ssh connection as your primary login method. Many applications expect more screen control than normally is available through a serial console. ssh from another Linux box will supply a better terminal emulation than Minicom.

7. Installing Software

Debian supports a huge package repository, the largest of any Linux distribution. Most any of these packages can be easily installed on OCTEON using the Debian package management system. The preferred interface to the package system is aptitude. Aptitude support both a command line interface as well as a curses based text GUI. For more detailed information, see the aptitude manual page. Below is a list of the most common keys needed in Aptitude.

  • ? - Short help on all of the keys
  • q - Exit current window. Exits Aptitude when the last window closes.
  • enter - Open a detailed information window about the selected item.
  • + - Mark the selected package for install
  • - - Mark the selected package for removal
  • L - Mark the selected package for reinstall
  • g - First display the changes that will be done, again to perform them
  • / - Search for a package
  • n - Continue a search
  • u - Update the package list for The Debian and Cavium Inc. web servers.
  • U - Upgrade any packages that have been changed by either Debian or Cavium Inc..

The Debian package management system maintains a database of all packages. This database needs to be update periodically to make sure you are getting the latest version of packages. Hitting the "u" key, or issuing the command "aptitude update" will update this database. These commands do not affect the installed packages, they just update the database. A symptom that you need to update the database is that some packages aren't found when installing them. Database updates are not only pulled from the Debian servers, but also Cavium's Debian repository. The Cavium repository has modified packages for OCTEON support that add to or replace parts of the Debian system.

Aptitude automatically handles all dependencies for a package. This makes it almost trivial to install very complicated packages. For example, to install Apache and start it serving web pages is simply:

    $ aptitude install apache

8. Compiling using the Debian Toolchain

The Debian toolchain is installed and in the PATH by default. This toolchain builds code with the O32 ABI and without any Cavium Inc. optimizations. This is the compiler to use for anything using the standard Debian libraries (/lib). Applications supporting auto configure and auto make should "just work". In general, this compiler should not be used. The OCTEON specific compilers supplied by Cavium generate much better code.

Results for "gcc -v":

  • Debian compiler: gcc version 4.9.2 (Debian 4.9.2-10)
  • Cavium compiler: gcc version 4.7.3 (Cavium Inc. Version: XXX)

9. Compiling using the OCTEON Optimized Toolchain

A Cavium Inc. optimized compiler is installed under /usr/local/Cavium_Networks/OCTEON-SDK/tools. This compiler builds code for either the N64 or the N32 ABI. Although code generated by this compiler cannot use the Debian libraries, it can execute seamlessly alongside the rest of the system. This toolchain should be used for application using OCTEON specific hardware. To use this compiler, set your PATH to find it before the Debian default.

N64 

        $ export PATH=/usr/local/Cavium_Networks/OCTEON-SDK/tools/usr/bin:${PATH}
        $ gcc -v

N32 

        $ export PATH=/usr/local/Cavium_Networks/OCTEON-SDK/tools/usr/bin32:${PATH}
        $ gcc -v

After setting your PATH, verify that the correct compiler is truly being used with "gcc -v". Specifically, check the vendor string that is part of the version information:

  • Debian compiler: gcc version ... (Debian ...)
  • Cavium compiler: gcc version ... (Cavium Inc. ...)

The compiler in bin32 is actually the same as in bin. The Mips option -mabi=n32 is passed automatically to as, gcc, and g++ in order to force the compiler to build N32 code.

10. Compact Flash Layout

The Debian compact flash is organized as two PC style partitions. The first partition is used for the kernel image vmlinux.64. This partition is used by the bootloader, so it uses the FAT16 filesystem (vfat under Linux). The second partition is an EXT3 filesystem containing the root filesystem for Debian. This partition can't be accessed from the bootloader.

Partition

Size

Filesystem

Debian Mount

Host Mount

Description

0

64MB

vfat

/boot

/mnt/cf1

Kernel and files for the Bootloader

1

500MB+

ext3

/

/mnt/cf2

Debian root filesystem

11. OCTEON Customizations to Debian

For those interested in the exact changes made to Debian for OCTEON, the makefile "Makefile.debootstrap" shows the process of bootstrapping the OCTEON version of Debian. Currently there are three changes incorporated into this distribution not found in the standard Debian distribution.

  1. Linux threads weak ordering support. glibc-linuxthreads was modified to preform the proper "sync" instructions during locks and atomic operations.
  2. OCTEON support in oprofile. The standard oprofile package from Debian does not support Mips. Oprofile version 0.9 with support for OCTEON performance counters was added to the distribution.
  3. OCTEON optimized toolchain. In addition to the normal Debian gcc and binutils, an OCTEON optimized version has been installed under /usr/local/Cavium_Networks. The support libraries for this toolchain are symbolically linked to /lib32, /lib64, /usr/lib32, and /usr/lib64. OCTEON II optimized toolchain are under /lib32/octeon2, lib64/octeon2, usr/lib32/octeon2, and /usr/lib64/octeon2. OCTEON III optimized toolchain are under /lib32/octeon3, lib64/octeon3, /usr/lib32/octeon3 and /usr/lib64/octeon3 directory.
